i have created an issue for lag_2 #1622

I have a question:
Where is planned to be used values from newly added "conf" key?

Also when I tried to apply changes from this PR and run "test_nbr_health.py" test case failed because of the issue which is mention in https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/1594

Output:
```
    @pytest.fixture(scope="module")
    def nbrhosts(ansible_adhoc, testbed, creds):
        """
        Shortcut fixture for getting VM host
        """

        vm_base = int(testbed['vm_base'][2:])
        devices = {}
        for k, v in testbed['topo']['properties']['topology']['VMs'].items():
            # devices[k] = EosHost(ansible_adhoc, "VM%04d" % (vm_base + v['vm_offset']), creds['eos_login'], creds['eos_password'])
            devices[k] = {'host': EosHost(ansible_adhoc, \
                                          "VM%04d" % (vm_base + v['vm_offset']), \
                                          creds['eos_login'], \
>                                         creds['eos_password']),
                          'conf': testbed['topo']['properties']['configuration'][k]}

conftest.py:210:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

common/devices.py:36: in __init__

_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

self = <pytest_ansible.host_manager.v28.HostManagerV28 object at 0x7fd7acd48690>, item = 'VM0704'

    def __getitem__(self, item):
        """Return a ModuleDispatcher instance described the provided `item`."""
        # Handle slicing
        if isinstance(item, slice):
            new_item = "all["
            if item.start is not None:
                new_item += str(item.start)
            new_item += '-'
            if item.stop is not None:
                new_item += str(item.stop)
            item = new_item + ']'

        if item in self.__dict__:
            return self.__dict__[item]
        else:
            if not self.has_matching_inventory(item):
>               raise KeyError(item)

```
this is separate issue. it is not addressed in this pr.

This pull request **fixes 1 alert** when merging b2e6abcd3f321500455dd17077521fafe3154382 into 8e608c3d9c928629dc130ca6c1b8f9b01eee2b91 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-90a7b6671ef186b80e59b102b2e737b46bb96f15)

what does dataplane.flush() achieve? does it delete all packets current in the rx buffer?

hi @lguohan, dataplane.flush() is defined in [ptf/dataplane.py](https://github.com/p4lang/ptf/blob/master/src/ptf/dataplane.py#L952) and is ued to clear all ports' queue content
```
    def flush(self):
        """
        Drop any queued packets.
        """
        for port_id in list(self.packet_queues.keys()):
            self.packet_queues[port_id] = []
```
If there are too many packets inside the queue, and the expected packets are in the tail of queue, the timeout (0.5) may not enough to done verification ([dp_poll](https://github.com/p4lang/ptf/blob/master/src/ptf/testutils.py#L2520)).  There are 2 possibile cases : 1) burst packets before this test case; 2) during verfication, new burst packets coming. This PR can prevent the case 1.
lgtm. @pavel-shirshov , can you check?

This change is ok for me. But I have a question: what kind of packets you're received in the queue?
Would it better to disable the packet generator, which sends you the 'noise' packets?
Most of packets receive from net ports, include bgp keepalive, bgp ack, lacp and lldp multicast.
@lguohan Please review
@lguohan Is there a way to specify different credentials for different vm_host?

Did the test pass on any DUT?

Why create new ferret.py and ferret.conf.j2?

Are they different from what we had before? If not, then they should be:

- symbolic link to old file. or
- move to new location and symbolic link from old place to new place.

Either way, we should have only one copy of these files.

> Why create new ferret.py and ferret.conf.j2?
> 
> Are they different from what we had before? If not, then they should be:
> 
> * symbolic link to old file. or
> * move to new location and symbolic link from old place to new place.
> 
> Either way, we should have only one copy of these files.

@yxieca It was common practice to have those files replicated inside pytest. The question is if we are going to remove the Ansible test down the road, should we be symlinking still?

> Did the test pass on any DUT?

Yes, internal s6100-2. Why?

> > Why create new ferret.py and ferret.conf.j2?
> > Are they different from what we had before? If not, then they should be:
> > 
> > * symbolic link to old file. or
> > * move to new location and symbolic link from old place to new place.
> > 
> > Either way, we should have only one copy of these files.
> 
> @yxieca It was common practice to have those files replicated inside pytest. The question is if we are going to remove the Ansible test down the road, should we be symlinking still?

My suggestion was to symlink from the pytest directory to the ansible directory. I think the plan is to delete the Ansible tests at some point but in the mean time if we need to make any bug fixes or anything like that during the transition period it would be nice to only have to update the script in one place.

> Why create new ferret.py and ferret.conf.j2?
> 
> Are they different from what we had before? If not, then they should be:
> 
> * symbolic link to old file. or
> * move to new location and symbolic link from old place to new place.
> 
> Either way, we should have only one copy of these files.

OK, I will remove to the new location and symlink then in the old one. This would make it easier had we decided to remove Ansible equivalent test cases

> > Did the test pass on any DUT?
> 
> Yes, internal s6100-2. Why?

It would be nice to have this information up front as part of the evidence that the test has been tested.

> Should this be under `system_utils` instead of platform? It doesn't really have to do with the device platform, it's more of a general testbed utility. (This is also a bit of a no-op until the community discussion about organizing the pytests, might be worth discussing later though. )

Well, platform would include the hardware and the OS. I've seen daemon_util in the platform dir. I see system (if you mean OS here) as a subset of platform. We certainly have discussion on having finer granular classification.

Hi ramakristipati

   Is spytest available now? I noticed that “For Scapy traffic generator refer to README.testbed.Setup.md” in sonic-mgmt/spytest/Doc/install.md. But the link points to sonic-mgmt/ansible/doc/README.testbed.Setup.md.
   So "sonic-mgmt/tests/" and "sonic-mgmt/spytest/" share the same testbed for PTF? Will "spytest" replace "test" later?

Yes, SPyTest works on the same PTF testbed.
Refer to README.testbed.md
<https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/ansible/README.testbed.md> for
setting up PTF-32 or PTF-64 topology.
This step is not needed if we are using Ixia/STC as a traffic generator.
Once the testbed is setup the SPyTest testbed file need to be created to
execute SPyTest tests
<https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/tree/master/spytest/tests>

@ramakristipati Please create subsequent PRs to address the LGTM alerts.

i think approach 1 is better because FanoutSwitch class can define its own method. In this case, we can define FanoutSwitch as the base class. 

We can not really use EosHost and SonicHost to inherit from FanoutSwitch.

Potentially, the FanoutSwitch can have following method:

shut/no_shut()
port_breakout()
set_interface_speed()
set_interface_fec()
send_pfc_frames()

some operations are especial to fanoutswitch class, like send_pfc_frames(). it does not make sense to implement that in the EosHost or SonicHost.
@yxieca , @wangxin  to comment.

> i think approach 1 is better because FanoutSwitch class can define its own method. In this case, we can define FanoutSwitch as the base class. 
> 
> 
> 
> We can not really use EosHost and SonicHost to inherit from FanoutSwitch.
> 
> 
> 
> Potentially, the FanoutSwitch can have following method:
> 
> 
> 
> shut/no_shut()
> 
> port_breakout()
> 
> set_interface_speed()
> 
> set_interface_fec()
> 
> send_pfc_frames()
> 
> 
> 
> some operations are especial to fanoutswitch class, like send_pfc_frames(). it does not make sense to implement that in the EosHost or SonicHost. 
> 
> 

Maybe my diagram mislead you...
The way I use here is not to inherit EOSHost and SONiCHost from FanoutHost, instead, I reference them directly inside the FanoutHost.

Test case contributor will only see FanoutHost, but the instance of FanoutHost will using EOSHost or *Host to implement it own interface.

Here is my concept:
```
# Current hosts
EOSHost extend AnsibleHostBase implement IInterfaceOperation, IPcrSender;
SONiCHost extend AnsibleHostBase implement IInterfaceOperation, IPcrSender;

# FanoutHost
FanoutHost implement IInterfaceOperation, IPcrSender {
  - host : EOSHost or SONiCHost or OtherHost
  …
}
```
Here we don't touch original EOSHost and SONiCHost, we simply use them API to implement  an abstract FanoutHost.

I vote for approach 1. 
If we use approach 2, the methods defined for the FanoutHost class eventually need to be implemented in the EOSHost and SoniCHost classes. The EOSHost and SoniChOST WILL be touched. For example, you have implemented `shutdown` and `no_shutdown` for EOSHost already and planned to implement them for SonicHost as well.

> I vote for approach 1.
> If we use approach 2, the methods defined for the FanoutHost class eventually need to be implemented in the EOSHost and SoniCHost classes. The EOSHost and SoniChOST WILL be touched. For example, you have implemented `shutdown` and `no_shutdown` for EOSHost already and planned to implement them for SonicHost as well.

@wangxin
If we want to use SONiC device as fanout switch, it is make sense to implement all fanout's API in SONiC host. With approach 1, you still need to implement it in SONiCFanoutSwitch too, right?

Approach 2 provided an exception handling: If we don't want to implement these API in SONiCHost immediately, the FanoutHost can simply raise an exception, then no one will be impact unless the testbed has a real SONiC Fanout and someone trying to invoking the unimplemented API.
The interface's implementation is not enforced because there are no 'abstract' keyword for interfaces, so no worry on touch existing class.

The approach 1 just like below diagram(let's use SONiC Host for an example):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6898708/78626890-a9718880-78c2-11ea-8c2e-a3f2b4b40c65.png)
It split SONiCHost by it usage. But, no matter the SONiC Host is a DUT or a Fanout, it is a SONiC, right? The different is the role and the usage of SONiC Host's API.
Yes, there are some SONiC API will only been used by Fanout by now, but somedays, those usage might form a new test case and been used by DUT, and we need to duplicate the same function in both SONiCHost and SONiCFanoutHost, I think that would hard to maintain.

For example, a vim programmer might never use [←][↑][↓][→] and his(her) kids might never use [esc]. It is unnecessary to buy two special keyboards for them because it will increase cost.

> It split SONiCHost by it usage. But, no matter the SONiC Host is a DUT or a Fanout, it is a SONiC, right? The different is the role and the usage of SONiC Host's API.

You made a point and convinced me. Thanks!
FYI, I updated the PR title to align with prevailing style.

> FYI, I updated the PR title to align with prevailing style.

Thank you for doing it

hi @pra-moh , 
May I know which component own this entry in the redis-db, thank you
 
```
results['FEATURES']={
'status': 'enabled'
}
```

> Should we add a setup check to make sure the telemetry container is alive before testing?

These parameters are needed before container starts.  We will be adding a separate test for the telemetry container to start successfully.

> hi @pra-moh ,
> May I know which component own this entry in the redis-db, thank you
> 
> ```
> results['FEATURES']={
> 'status': 'enabled'
> }

https://sonic-jenkins.westus2.cloudapp.azure.com/job/vs/job/buildimage-vs-image-pr/3108/console

this is the error message for previous pr.

what is corefile_uploader['env'] is not defined?

The error was not because 'env' is not defined, but overloaded quotes. It is a syntax error.
line: '\1https_proxy": "{{ corefile_uploader['env']['https_proxy'] }}"'

The entire line is wrapped in single quote, and I used single quote inside too, around env, which totally compiles out as 
'\1https_proxy": "{{ corefile_uploader['   +  env  + ']['https_proxy'] }}"'
Here env is expected as variable/fact which is not the case.

In new code, I read it separately and use the read value to fill, so no too many quotes issue.
The code explicitly check for "when: corefile_uploader['env']['https_proxy'] is defined"

In fact, it compiled out as 
'\1https_proxy": "{{ corefile_uploader[' + env + '][' + https_proxy + '] }}"'

can you provide sample var file in group_vars/all/corefile_uploader.yml

just commented so that if external user want to use, they know how to provide those data?

There are two big open questions for this PR (so far):
1. Should `docker_registry.yml` be moved/copied out of the ansible directory?
2. ~How should we approach the password field for `docker login`? The concern is that the password will be exposed in the logs in the current code. My thought is to use the --password-stdin field that Docker provides, but I'm wondering if @lguohan or @wangxin have handled this before or know of a good way to approach this.~
